newsitem.title: UK: UK's Mackay to retire as Lord Chancellor.
newsitem.headline: UK's Mackay to retire as Lord Chancellor.

text.p: Lord James Mackay of Clashfern will step down as Lord Chancellor on age grounds after Britain's coming election, the government said on Monday.
Mackay is the second member of the cabinet, after Northern Ireland Secretary Sir Patrick Mayhew, to announce his retirement at the election, which will be held on May 1.
Mackay, the head of the judiciary, said he was approaching the age of 70 -- the retirement age for judges set down in an act of parliament that he himself promoted.
"I will myself reach that age in July, and I think it right that I should abide by that rule," he said in a letter to Prime Minister John Major.
Major thanked Mackay for his wise advice and record of great distinction.
"You have served with enormous skill, patience and dignity as Lord Chancellor for almost 10 years -- the longest continuous service of a Lord Chancellor this century.

"You have succeeded in combining leadership of the legal profession with a number of important reforms, which are significantly improving the administration of justice," Major said in a letter to Mackay released by his office.
